greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Swap each prime in factorization of n with "neighbor" prime.
comment: Here "neighbor" primes are just paired in order: 2<->3, 5<->7, 11<->13, etc. Self-inverse permutation of the integers. Multiplicative.
link: Alois P. Heinz, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..20000
Index entries for sequences that are permutations of the natural numbers
example: a(60) = 126 since 60 = 2^2*3*5, swapping 2<->3 and 5<->7 gives 3^2*2*7 = 126 (and of course then a(126) = 60).
mathematica: Array[a, 80] (* _Jean-François Alcover_, Jun 10 2018, after _Alois P. Heinz_ *)
program: (PARI) a(n) = my(f=factor(n)); for (i=1, #f~, ip = primepi(f[i,1]); if (ip % 2, f[i,1] = prime(ip+1), f[i,1] = prime(ip-1))); factorback(f); \\ _Michel Marcus_, Jun 09 2014
results.author: _Marc LeBrun_, May 14 2001
